div1.p: United States District Court Western District of Washington Northern Division.
In the Matter of the Application of Ching Hing for a Writ of Habeas Corpus } No. 2857 Memorandum Brief.
Statement of Facts.
In this case the sole reason for granting the Writ of Habeas Corpus was that neither the Secretary of Labor nor his Assistant reviewed the decision of the Commissioner of Immigration, Henry M. White.

At the first hearing the petitioner asked that the case be continued to take the deposition of the Secretary of Labor and his Assistant in Washington, D.C., and the Court issued an order granting a commission to take the depositions. Before the depositions were returned the Secretary of Labor himself reviewed the decision of Comissioner White and affirmed it, and thereupon the respondent moved the Court to cancel the order to take depositions in Washington, on the ground that the depositiion were made useless by the proper authorities rectifying the alleged injustice done to the petitioner.
Law and Argument
The statute on this subject provides as follows:

"In every case where an alien is excluded from admission into the United States under any law or treaty now existing, or hereafter made, the decision of the appropriate customs or immigration officer, if adverse to the admission of such alien, shall be final, unless reversed on appeal to the secretary of the treasury. 28 Stat. 390"

It seems to us that the statute settles the law, because Commissioner White's decision is final unless reversed. Even if the wrong oficers affirmed Commissioner White's decision, the Court could not say that he was reversed, but if the Court should take the view adopted by Judge Dooling, and by the courtesy of Mr. Sulliven, filed in this action, that the Secretary of Labor or his Assistant must review the appeal, it seems to us that the Court will follow the Judge along through and adopt the very equitable course which he pursued.
It will be observed that though the Judge held that the Secretary or his Assistant should review the case when present in the office, he stated (page 4 of decision) -

"This being the first time that this question has been presented to the court, the petitioners were not discharged, but it was ordered that their deportation be stayed until their appeal had been heard and determined by competent authority, and if such appeal was not so heard and determined within fifteen days from October 5th, 1914, that they might apply to the court for further relief."

And even though the Department did not conform to the very equitable decision of the Judge, yet he still refused to release the alien, and said that the case was still pending on appeal at Washington, and the Court said (page 6 of decision)-
"But it does not follow from this that the petitioners here are entitled to an absolute discharge. As said by Judge Gilbert in the case of Way Tai, 96 Fed. 484:

'If the Assistant Secretary had not the authority to hear and determine the appeal, the appeal has not been disposed of, but is still pending, and the detention of the petitioner by the officer to whom he was intrusted until the dispostition of his case on appeal is not unlawful.'

The Department, however, while still holding the petitioners in custody for deportation, is apparaently indisposed to have the appeal heard by any one whom (2)
the court believes to be authorized to hear it. The Court is not disposed to land these aliens when the local officers have decided against their right to land, and while in the language of Judge Gilbert above quoted their appeal is still pending."
The Court will find the quotation from the Way Tai case, made by Judge Dooling, in 96 Fed. 486, near the bottom of the page, and will see that that decision absolutely upholds Judge Dooling.

We submit that there is no distinction between that case and this. We are not endeavoring to play fast and loose with this Court. A petition for habeas corpus determines whether or not the petitioner is in the legal custody of the Immigration authorities. This does not suspend the appeal. It leaves the case of the Chinaman in status quo and if the Immigration authorities desire to make further orders therein they can do so. There is no injunction by the court to stop them.

In this case the authorities at Washington evidently decided that Judge Dooling might be right and they would not contest the point, and so they said we will get the proper man to review this case and rectify the alleged injustices done to the petitioner.

We do not see why this Court should wait until the depostitions come back from Washington and the determine whether or not the Secretary of Labor or his Assistant should hear the appeal, and then if he should rule that the Secretary or his Assistant should hear the appeal, continue the case as Judge Dooling did for fifteen or thirty days until said Secretary or Assistant could give exactly the same decision which we are offering in evidence.

The point we make is that by the action of the Secretary (3)
of Labor in deciding this case in person, all the questions raised in the petition are moot questions, and we are familiar enough with the amount of work which this Court is compeeled to perform to know that he will not decide any question unless absolutely necessary to a fair decision of the case.
Objection That Record Not At Washington When Secretary Reviewed Decision.

It was strenously argued by the attorney on the other side that the Secretary of Commerce and Labor could not have considered this case on appeal because we had the original record filed and made an exhibit in this cause.

The practice in these cases is that the Immigration office makes out a duplicate record, the original and the copy both being considered orginals by the Department. When we make the record a part of our return we always use what would be a carbon copy, according to state practice, but what according to the Immigration office is considered one of the originals.

In this case we used the carbon copy which was at Commissioner White's office, adn the original of this carbon wass in Washington. If the Court thinks it necessary we can call this a copy and we will ask the Court that we may amend our Return by inserting between the words "that" and "the record" in line 15, on page 2, the words "a copy of."
The Court will see that this is the case by reading the second paragraph in the letter on page 48 of the record which is as follows:

"As this case was decided upon the record as submitted by you, and as you have been furnished a copy of the (4)
Bureau's memorandum which was approved by the Department, it is not considered necessary to forward you the record certified by the Department. You can use your own copy in making return to the writ."
And also by the words occuring in the decision offered in evidence by the governmnet as exhibit "B" in the following language:

"It is believed that the inclosed will serve your purpose, without withdrawing from the Bureau's files the entire record, of which you already possess a complete copy with the exception of the notation on the memorandum of the Secretary's approval."

This habeas corpus proceedings is not an appeal. It is merely to determine whether this Chinaman is properly held. Until Commissioner White is reversed by the Secretary of Labor one of two things is true, either that Commissioner White's decision is still in force and no one can interfere with it until it is reversed and properly by appeal, or this case is pending on appeal before the Department in Washington and is awaiting the decision of the proper official in order to sustain the petition. The petition has to establish in direct language and by inference that the Chinaman and the Chinaman's case is within the power and jurisdiction and authority of the Immigration authorities, otherwise he could not make them respondents to his action; so the very petition itself says that we still have jurisdiction; that the matter is still pending before us, and there is no injunction, execution or order of a court of record suspending the action of the Immigration authorities.
We believe that this answers all of the points raised by opposing counsel, and respectfully submit that the petition should be dismissed and the alien remanded to the proper authorities.
